    Head M (cont.) -

    Resumption of debate on Question [10th March, 1993],

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head M of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code MC 1500." - [Dr John Chen Seow Phun].

    Question again proposed.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC): Sir, the quantity of waste generated is increasing quite rapidly as Singaporeans become more and more affluent. Waste output for the first 11 months of 1992 averaged 6,160 tons per day, an increase of 4.5% over the 1991 average. Industrial and commercial waste makes up 51% of the waste disposed of, whereas domestic and trade waste makes up the remaining 49%. For resource conservation and to reduce the costs of waste collection and disposal, we should therefore have an effective waste minimisation and management programme.

    One way is to step up our recycling programme. The Ministry started a number of recycling centres sometime ago. I was told that some of these centres suffer the problem of people throwing into bins all kinds of rubbish indiscriminately. Will the Minister give us an update on the effectiveness of the scheme and whether there is any other approach the Ministry is considering to encourage recycling?

    Sir, incineration of rubbish also helps recycling. We generate electricity and recover iron from the waste. I would like to ask the Minister: how much more of the rubbish we generate can be incinerated? And if we are not burning all the rubbish that can be incinerated, can the Minister tell us why?

Column: 962



    Sir, another way to encourage waste reduction is to charge economic costs for waste removal. At present, households are charged a flat rate for refuse removal. There have been suggestions that refuse removal fees should be tied to the actual quantities of refuse to be disposed of. Can the Minister tell us whether he is considering such a move and how it can be implemented?

    Sir, the cost of refuse removal also depends on the cost of hiring workers and the methods adopted. All of us are aware that there is a shortage of refuse removal and cleansing workers in Singapore. This is evident in the reduced frequency of cleansing, the increasing reliance on older workers and some mechanisation that we see.

    I therefore want to know whether the Government is taking a national approach towards this problem. For instance, in the case of mechanisation, there is a need to take a total look at the whole country and ensure that all the compounds, the streets, the buildings and so on are either modified or improved to become more machine friendly. I provide an example here. In the early days of tree planting, we went around planting many trees to achieve a certain objective. But I am not sure whether we were aware then that some of these trees could pose problems to mechanisation today.

    Sir, the Government should also look at other available systems such as the sewers to carry disintegrated solids to certain points for disposal. May I have the response of the Minister, please?

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, there are laws in Singapore to control the pollution of our environment, for example, proper disposal of rubbish and indiscriminate burning of substances in open air. But, as yet, there is no comprehensive set of provision to regulate noise pollution which can endanger health as well as impoverish the quality of life.

    Sir, we have to live very closely together with one another as living space is a scarce commodity in Singapore. The need

Column: 963

to tolerate the hustle and bustle of living side by side with or on top of one another goes without saying. But living in close proximity to one another need not have to mean doing so with unnecessarily loud, distracting or irritating noises.

    Sir, my concern is that, with the passing of each year, more and more of Singapore will be built up and the level of noise pollution will become intolerable. It would be impractical and unrealistic to ban all noises above a certain level of decibels on a 24-hour basis. I do not think anyone in or outside this House wants to ban the banging of cymbals, gongs and drums at religious festivals. But it is pointless for Singaporeans to slog themselves out to own homes if they cannot have peaceful enjoyment of their homes at any time.

    A balance has to be found between the need for such peaceful enjoyment and the need for Singapore to allow vital economic activities to be carried out, even if these activities are sources of noise pollution. One way may be to restrict noisy activities at night, say, between 11.00 pm and 7.00 am. Another way is to confine noisy activities to non-residential areas, if possible. Or to use less noisy modes for carrying out noisy activities or to use noise-dampening materials, for example, on expressways. I should therefore like to know whether the Government has any plan to enact comprehensive legislation on noise pollution in future.

     Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar GRC): Sir, I agree with Mr Chin Harn Tong's point of view. But I am more interested to know about noise pollution created by vehicles.

    Sir, for your information, the Central Expressway (CTE) cuts my Kallang Division into two parts. On the one side, you have Kallang Estate and, on the other side, you have Whampoa Estate. I have been receiving complaints from residents that the vehicles plying up and down the CTE have created unbearable noise. I am sure this kind of noise pollution is not peculiar to my constituency. I would like to know whether the Ministry has any plans

Column: 964

to tackle noise pollution problem, apart from planting more trees along the expressway, and whether the Ministry will conduct any spot checks on excessive noise created by vehicles, especially motor-cycles.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, the Government launched a Green Labelling Scheme last year and a number of product categories were released to promote green consumerism. The success of this scheme will be judged not just by the initial number of companies applying to join the scheme, but also by the response of the consumers to the green products. Can the Minister tell us what is the progress made on Green Labelling, whether the green products have received good response from the consumers, and what else the Ministry would do to further promote green consumerism?

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Chairman, Sir, let me fist deal with the subject of Privatisation of Hawker Centres. However, I would like to inform this House and, in particular, hon. Members who spoke on the subject at yesterday's sitting, that I will be speaking in general terms as many of the details of the scheme are still being worked out.

    Sir, the Government is looking into the possibility of selling hawker stalls to incumbent stallholders. After buying over the stalls, the hawkers can, as suggested by Mr Peh Chin Hua yesterday, form management committees to manage the respective hawker centres. The terms and conditions of the sale will be made as attractive as possible. The selling price will be kept affordable and the details of the terms and conditions of sale and selling price will be announced later.

    Sir, I may add that the privatisation proposal for hawker centres is separate and distinct from the recent tendering of vacant wet market stalls. The vacant wet market stalls that were put out for tender recently were in excess of what we need for resettlement purposes. Let me assure Members of this House that stalls that are already occupied will not be tendered out. It is our intention to sell them to incumbent stallholders.

Column: 965



    On the subject of Refuse Collection, Sir, I must thank Mr Chew Heng Ching for bringing up a very real concern which my Ministry faces. In the short term, my Ministry will attempt to overcome the manpower shortage by introducing more labour-saving methods for refuse collection. For example, refuse compactors will be installed at more bin centres. However, in the longer term, Sir, we will need the support and the cooperation of the community at large. In countries like the UK and indeed in the US and other countries in Europe, households give a lot of cooperation to refuse collectors. In these countries, refuse is collected once a week. In order to minimise littering and other public health problems, residents bring out the refuse on collection day.

    Sir, in Singapore, everyone should also cooperate and not take refuse collection for granted. For example, for the 85% of residents living in flats, if they were to bag their refuse before dropping them into the chutes, the workmen will certainly find it much easier to empty the bins at the chute. For those who live in landed property, the one-man-operated (OMO) method may be a possible way of reducing the number of refuse collection workers required. Alternate-day collection may be another alternative.

    But really, Sir, if everyone practises waste minimisation through reuse and recycling, there will be less waste and we may not even need the extra workmen in future. But whatever it is, my Ministry will continue to provide a good level of refuse collection service despite the manpower shortage.

    Mr Charles Chong yesterday spoke of complaints from Pasir Ris residents about the non-collection of refuse from their centralised refuse chutes and he wanted to know what my Ministry proposes to do to deal with such situation so that refuse would be collected regularly.

    Sir, refuse thrown down the centralised chutes is collected in special bins at the bottom of the chutes. As the quantity in each bin is large, the refuse has to be mechanically removed by our refuse

Column: 966

trucks. Indiscriminate parking of vehicles in front of these chutes obstructs our operation. This is becoming quite a serious problem and is preventing the removal of refuse from centralised refuse chutes in a number of housing estates. My Ministry is working with the HDB and several town councils to see how best obstruction caused by illegal parking can be minimised. I would also like to seek the cooperation of motorists to refrain from parking illegally in front of centralised refuse chutes and bin centres.
12.45 pm

    Mr Goh Choon Kang yesterday expressed concern over the effect of tendering out hawker stalls on food prices. Let me at the outset clarify that, apart from the four hawker stalls at Newton Food Centre, the other stalls that were put up for tender recently were the vacant wet market stalls. As I have said earlier, these vacant wet market stalls were in excess of what we need for resettlement purposes.

    Sir, food prices are not likely to rise as a result of the tendering out of these vacant wet market stalls. The number of vacant wet market stalls put up for tender forms only a small proportion of the overall number. For example, the Buffalo Road Market has about 400 stalls, of which only 13 were tendered out. These 13 stalls will not be able to compete with the rest in the market if their food prices were high. In fact, food prices in private dry markets are comparable to those in wet markets even though dry market stallholders pay very much higher rentals.

    Sir, tendering is a more efficient and equitable method of allocating limited resources. In the past, applicants for hawker stalls had to participate in ballots. Success depended on luck, rather than on their ability to provide good service to the customers.

    On the subject of dengue haemorrhagic fever, I am happy to say that the outbreak of the disease which occurred last year has been brought under control. The average number of cases over the past two months was 16 per week as compared to 55 cases per week last year. Nearly

Column: 967

5,000 households were fined for breeding mosquitoes within their premises last year. Three repeat offenders were prosecuted in court. Although the overall situation has improved, I would still like to urge Singaporeans to continue to take steps to prevent mosquito breeding. Sir, as the population of Aedes mosquitoes increases in a neighbourhood, that neighbourhood comes under threat of dengue haemorrhagic fever outbreak.

    Public health education will be my Ministry's overall strategy. We will also strengthen our monitoring and surveillance capabilities by building a quicker and more responsive alert system. This will enable any localised build-up of Aedes mosquitoes to be detected early so that ground operations can be mobilised quickly. For the information of this House, by the middle of this year, our surveillance programme will be fully computerised.

    On the subject of waste minimisation, this House may wish to note that the Green Plan Workgroup on Resource Conservation has made a number of recommendations to discourage excessive waste generation. One of the recommendations of the Workgroup is for households to pay by the amount of refuse discarded. In this way, the Workgroup hopes that less refuse will be generated as households curb their refuse output in order to save on refuse removal fees.

    Such a volume-based fee can take a number of forms. My Ministry is presently considering two alternatives: the Pre-paid Bag System and the Variable Bin System for landed properties.

    What are these systems? The Pre-paid Bag System requires households to buy special bags for their refuse. The price of each bag will include the refuse removal fee. So households which throw out less rubbish will spend less on the bags.

    The Variable Bin System requires each household to obtain special bins for its refuse and the monthly refuse removal fee will depend on the size of the bin. By

Column: 968

throwing less away, a smaller bin will be needed and the household will pay a lower fee.

    Sir, the introduction of a volume-based fee system will be a major change for Singapore. My Ministry will be considering these proposals very, very carefully before any decision is taken. We will not rush into it.

    On the subject of recycling brought up by Dr John Chen, our assessment is that it has achieved its objective of encouraging members of the public to practise resource conservation. Since the launching of the recycling programme, my Ministry has set up a total of 58 recycling centres. I agree with Dr Chen that there are some people who misuse the recycling bins, but I am happy to say that they form a small minority.

    The Member may wish to know that apart from recycling bins, my Ministry has also launched a pilot project in a housing estate for door-to-door collection of recyclable materials. We will also be launching a purpose-built recycling collection vehicle to serve about 10 private residential estates in the Bukit Timah area as part of my Ministry's expansion of the recycling programme.

    Dr Chen, like Mr Chew Heng Ching yesterday, has touched on a problem that my Ministry is most mindful of when he spoke on the shortage of public cleansing workers. Because of the problem we anticipate, my Ministry has over the years progressively introduced mechanisation to replace manual workers. For example, we are now trying out a small mobile machine to clean open parks and walkways. If proven successful, this machine can replace a few workers. But in the longer-term, there will be a limit to mechanisation and it will be necessary and crucial to have the community's support and cooperation. If everyone can help keep our public places clean by not littering, we will need fewer workers for public cleansing.

    As to whether Government takes a national approach in attempting to solve the cleansing of public places, the answer is yes. My Ministry does consult other

Column: 969

relevant authorities, when necessary, to ensure that designs or modifications of infrastructures take into account public cleansing, especially in areas where it may not be possible to mechanise. For example, we got the PWD to redesign the inlet to the scupper drains as the older design gave rise to cleansing problems. We have also got the PWD to provide ramps for pedestrian malls and walkways to facilitate the use of mechanised mobile cleansing machines. Sometime ago, we also convinced the Parks and Recreation Department not to plant Ketapang trees as they shed leaves continuously which clogged up drains and drain outlets.

    Dr Chen also wants to know how much more of the rubbish we generate can be incinerated. With the completion of the third incineration plant at Senoko, we now have a total incineration capacity of 5,700 tonnes per day and we are able to burn all incinerable refuse generated up to the year 1997.

    With regard to his suggestion that sewers carry disintegrated solids to certain points for disposal, I will certainly ask the relevant department of my Ministry to look into the proposal.

    Let me turn to the subject of noise pollution. It will not be possible to eliminate noise. We can only minimise its impact. So to control noise, our primary focus will be on preventive measures to minimise noise impact.

    As far as possible, we will use appropriate engineering or planning measures to do this. For example, to reduce traffic noise from expressways, the PWD has implemented several measures such as lowering the road gradient, optimising traffic flows and controlling speed limits. The PWD is also looking into the feasibility of using noise absorbing materials for paving roads. And to cut down traffic noise level further, the ROV is currently examining the noise emission standards for vehicles.

    Sir, we have the necessary legislation to control various types of noise and these are enforced by several appropriate authorities. But the House may be interested to know that the Green Plan

Column: 970

Workgroup on Noise has recommended the setting up of a central unit in my Ministry to ensure that controls by the various authorities are guided by well-coordinated policy directions and objectives. Apart from a few areas where new legislation may be required, existing laws are sufficiently comprehensive.

    I will now answer some of the issues raised by Mr Choo Wee Khiang. To minimise the impact of noise from the CTE, residential developments in the vicinity of the CTE are kept at least 30 metres away from the expressway. The PWD, as I have mentioned earlier on, has implemented several other measures to minimise the impact of traffic noise from the Central Expressway.

    Sir, on Green Labelling, the Scheme now covers 5 product categories - 4 on recycled paper products and 1 on carbon-zinc batteries. In the next 4 months, another eight product categories will be introduced and these include alkaline batteries, compact fluorescent lamps and detergents.

    Since my Ministry introduced the Green Labelling Scheme in August last year, we have received enthusiastic response from manufacturers and retailers to participate in the Scheme. A recent survey conducted by my Ministry showed that support from members of the public for Green Label products has also been encouraging. Six of the 15 companies surveyed reported an increase in the sale of Green Label products ranging from 2% to 60%. And I would certainly like to congratulate our environment-friendly citizens who have made a choice to protect our environment.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, before I withdraw the amendment, I would like the Minister to consider carefully the implications of the two alternatives that he mentioned for the collection of refuse. First, by using a pre-paid bag, we may cut down the volume, but not necessarily the weight, which means that the waste generated can still be the same, but it is easier for collection. Secondly, the variable bin might encourage people to dump their rubbish into other people's bin. These are the implications that I hope the Minister will look into.

Column: 971



    Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

     The Chairman: Amendment Nos. (3) and (4), Mr Yap is not here. Amendment No. (5), Dr John Chen.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head M of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code MF 1500.

    Sir, the variety and volume of chemicals and chemical products handled in Singapore have been increasing rapidly due to the success of our industrialisation programme. While this contributes significantly to our economy, it will also pose a great challenge to both the industries and the Government to maintain a safe and healthy environment expected by the workers and the public.
1.00 pm

    The Government has so far been able to avoid major chemical disasters through stringent controls and legislation. However, some of the chemical plants have been in existence for some years now. Whether the original design for safety controls is adequate or is still within the safety standards after a number of years of wearing down is of great concern to the workers and the public. There is therefore a need for companies in the chemical industry to perform regular safety audits for their plants. May I ask the Minister whether such requirement is being worked out for these companies to follow so as to protect both our workers and the environment.

     Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Thomson GRC): Sir, our vehicle population is rising. With more cars on the road, the total amount of pollution emitted from our vehicles will rise. If this trend is not checked, this pollution will be to the detriment of our air quality. Although our air quality is currently safe, we have to ensure that it continues to be so. The Ministry of the Environment has introduced a variety of measures to control

Column: 972

pollution from vehicles. Would the Minister inform the House if the measures taken so far have been adequate and the effect these measures have had on our air quality?

     Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, the emission from road transport vehicles is a major source of air pollution in urban areas. At present, diesel and gasoline are the two major fuels used for road transport. It is well know that gasoline emits relatively high levels of carbon monoxide, nitrogen-oxide and unburnt hydro-carbon. It is also well known that the diesel vehicle emits an unpleasant odour and also particulates. The latter is known to be carcinogenic.

    After the introduction of compulsory three-way catalytic converter for gasoline cars, we may manage to reduce the pollutants from the gasoline cars to the minimum possible level. However, the control of the diesel vehicle pollution is still considered relatively loose. I feel that when the technology and cost are feasible, the Ministry should consider the compulsory installation of particulate trap for diesel vehicles.

    Sir, electric cars should be ideal for our urban transport environment. However, it is still difficult to break through because of the problem of charging time, minimum distance for each charging, life of the battery and cost. So perhaps the short term solution is to introduce alternative fuels to further reduce the pollution generated by the vehicles. Many options are available. These include liquified petroleum gas (LPG), compressed natural gas (CNG) and partial blend of alcohol or methanol with petrol or diesel. Out of all these options, I feel that compressed natural gas could be economically viable to the unique condition in Singapore. This is because at the moment we do have natural gas directly piped in from Malaysia and Indonesia at quite affordable and competitive price.

    Sir, CNG is a premium fuel and it will help the gasoline cars or spark ignition cars to reduce its emission of hydro-carbon and carbon monoxide. Due to the problems of handling CNG, at the moment

Column: 973

it can only be applied to cars instead of trucks or heavy vehicles like buses. At the moment, many countries, like Japan, New Zealand and Australia, have replaced the polluted diesel taxis by using CNG-propelled spark ignition taxis. Sir, we can learn from the experience of all these countries. Perhaps, not too far in the future, the Ministry could consider allowing CNG-propelled taxis to be on our roads to further reduce air pollution in Singapore.

    At present, the rule guiding the use of such environment-friendly vehicles is either not in place or not friendly enough. I would just cite an example, like the using of LPG cars. The recent rule states that the owner of an LPG car is required to pay diesel tax which deters all the potential users. I suggest that the Ministry should put certain regulations in place to encourage people to use the environment-friendly vehicles. We should provide some incentives, if possible. But we must not provide disincentives to discourage ownership of such vehicles.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, at the fourth meeting of parties to the Montreal Protocol held in Copenhagen in November 1992, the phase-out schedules of CFCs and other ozone-depleting substances of the Montreal Protocol had been accelerated. Is Singapore complying with this accelerated phase-out schedule?

    I understand that the phasing out of ozone-depleting substances will not only affect our industries, but it will also affect the general public. Most of our air-conditioning systems for offices, homes and cars use coolants which are CFC-based. Their systems will probably have to be modified when such coolants become unavailable.

    Would the Minister tell us when will our offices, homes and cars be affected, whether there is a replacement for the coolants, and if not, what are the things people need to do to continue using their air-conditioning systems?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Chairman, Sir, on the subject of safety audits for the chemical industry, I would like to emphasise that all aspects pertaining to

Column: 974

safety are carefully studied before a chemical plant is allowed to be set up in Singapore. Of primary importance, Sir, is the proper siting of these chemical plants away from congested public places. The design of the plant must also incorporate whatever safety measures and controls that may be imposed as a result of the study. All these measures and controls will, to a large extent, minimise the potential hazards.

    At present, chemical plants are regularly checked by the relevant authorities, such as the Department of Industrial Safety of the Ministry of Labour, the Fire Safety Bureau of the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Pollution Control Department of my Ministry, to ensure continued compliance with the requirements. They are also required to seek approval for any major changes which may affect the safety environment of the plants.

    Requiring companies, new and old, which operate chemical plants or potentially hazardous factories to comply with all the statutory safety measures will prevent accidents. It is also in the interest of such companies to conduct their own safety audits regularly, as suggested by Dr Chen. Such audits can be undertaken by in-house safety professionals or specialist safety consultants. I believe the Ministry of Labour is currently conducting a study to identify these companies and to encourage them to conduct safety audits.

    On the subject of vehicle emission control, as raised by the Member for Thomson GRC, the House may want to know that over the years we have adopted various measures to keep our air clean. These measures include the use of cleaner fuels and the adoption of stricter emission standards. With these measures, air pollution levels in Singapore have either dropped or held steady, although there are now 40% more vehicles on our roads than in 1981.

    Sir, the improvement in the ambient lead level is most significant. The level, as it stands today, is only one-seventh of the 1981 level. Half the cars that can run on unleaded petrol have already switched to the cleaner fuel. What I would like to do is

Column: 975

to urge the remaining half to switch to unleaded petrol so that our air will be even cleaner. Sir, the experience over the last two years shows that unleaded petrol does not lower engine performance. Besides, it is much cheaper.

    Sir, the levels of carbon monoxide and sulphur dioxide in our air have also improved. They are now about 70% of their respective levels in 1981. Hydrocarbon and particulate levels are steady. However, the roadside levels of nitrogen oxides are slowly rising.

    The levels of all these pollutants will rise if more cars are added to our roads. Therefore, to keep them from rising, we must continue to adopt more stringent emission limits and to use cleaner fuels.

    Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to announce that from 1996 the sulphur level in automotive diesel will be reduced from the current limit of 0.5% by weight to 0.3% by weight.      The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Sir, I wish to thank all the speakers for their views and suggestions. They have covered a very wide range of topics. I would, first, like to deal with the question of autonomous schools because it is something that is of great interest to the public after it was announced by the Prime Minister last year.
4.45 pm

    The Government has succeeded in providing adequate school facilities and a good standard of education for our children. For example, for the 1992 batch of "O" level students, there were about 35,000 students who took the examination and 89% scored three or more 'O' level passes. 70% scored five or more 'O' level passes. I think this is a very credible performance and we are seeing improvement year by year, which is only possible with the hard work of all the teachers, staff and the children, of course, and because we have been putting so much emphasis on education.

    Now, the emphasis, henceforth, will be on raising the quality of education. Learning from the experience of outstanding private and independent schools in the UK and US, the conclusion was that excellence in education can be achieved by allowing selected schools to go independent. Such schools should be well managed, with a good track record

Column: 1041

and long traditions of scholastic achievement. Since 1988, eight secondary schools in Singapore have become independent schools. They are allowed to charge fees ranging from $70 to $200 per month as compared to $12 to $14 charged by Government and aided schools.

    With the additional resources and with autonomy over school management, the independent schools are able to introduce innovations to their school organisation and programmes. The Government provides financial assistance and Edusave scholarships to deserving pupils so that no student who is able to qualify for admission to independent schools is prevented from doing so by financial circumstances. Useful lessons from the independent schools can be applied to other schools to help them improve. A good example is the provision of Edusave block grants averaging $100,000 per annum to all Government and aided secondary schools to give them greater financial flexibility.

    Another is the Government's decision to create a group of autonomous schools to complement the independent schools. The selected schools will be given additional resources and greater autonomy to function more like independent schools. However, their fees will be kept low. Pupils will, therefore, have more good schools to choose from.

    Let me now touch briefly on the key factors of the autonomous schools.

Legal status

    Autonomous schools will retain their status as Government or aided schools.

Personnel

    To be successful, a school must have an energetic, capable and dedicated principal with a keen sense of mission. He needs a strong team of teachers who share the same goals and vision The principal of an autonomous school will, therefore, be given a greater role in the selection of staff for the school so that he can build up an effective team.

Column: 1042



Staffing norm

    To keep costs down, autonomous schools will retain the present class size and staffing norm. However, they will be able to hire additional staff on contract basis for enrichment programmes and support services.

Funding

    The annual running cost of Government secondary schools is about $3,500 per pupil. The Government will provide 10% more funding or about $350 more per pupil per annum to autonomous schools as a block grant. Parents should also play their part by contributing about 1% of the per capita cost or about $3 per month more in miscellaneous fees. The school will also receive the normal Edusave grant which averages $100,000 per annum. All in, the additional fund will be almost $700,000 per year for an enrolment of 1,500. This will be sufficient for the school to introduce various innovative and enhancement programmes. If additional funding is required, the autonomous schools will be allowed to raise miscellaneous fees further by up to 5% of the per capita cost or about $15 per month and the Government will match this dollar for dollar.

Fees

    There is some concern about fees. Let me explain the situation. Autonomous schools will thus charge the normal fee of $12 to $14 per month. This consists of $5 school fee and $7 miscellaneous fees in the normal case but schools have the discretion to raise the miscellaneous fees by another 30% and so it may be another $2 more. Right now, the secondary schools are charging a total of either $12 or $14. The autonomous schools will charge $3 more in miscellaneous fees. So the Government will provide 10% more in terms of per capita cost, the parents provide 1% more, and the 1% is equivalent to $3 per month. So instead of $12 to $14 total fees, the schools could raise the fees by $3, making a total of either $15 or $17. This will be the base case. But if the schools need to have more funding because they want to have more programmes, then they will be allowed

Column: 1043

to charge up to another $15 per month in miscellaneous fees. Total fees will, therefore, be between $15 and $32 per month which should be affordable to most parents. The bulk of the additional funding will be provided by the Government.

Curriculum

    Autonomous schools will adhere to broad educational policies, for example, the bilingual policy and offer a core curriculum for the GCE examinations as is done in all secondary schools. They will be given the same autonomy as independent schools in offering elective subjects.

Admission of pupils

    Autonomous schools will admit pupils according to merit as is the case with Government and aided schools. Thus, they will continue to be accessible to all pupils based on their PSLE results.

    My Ministry will be selecting four to six schools which will function as autonomous schools from January next year. The selection process will take into account the school's track record, type of school, the quality of school leadership and geographical location. The plan is to have 10 to 15 autonomous schools spread throughout Singapore in the next few years. Schools will compete to be selected as autonomous schools based on their performance and track record. It is likely that some of these schools will be good neighbourhood schools with a long history of good performance. The schools will be announced sometime in the later part of this year, before August, so that pupils will have a chance to apply for admission to those schools and qualify on the basis of their PSLE results.

    Sir, our education system is a good example of the process of levelling up of our society. We should develop every child to his maximum potential. We should encourage our brightest and ablest to rise as far as they can and not hold them back resulting from politics of envy. Our brightest children are our future leaders, our cutting edge. Even the Communist government in the PRC talent spots its most gifted children and puts

Column: 1044

them through special education and training. Hence, in our Singapore context we have been setting up independent schools to try and raise the quality of our school system. The Government provides the same per capita grant as for the other schools. Parents pay for the extra in the independent schools. They get the same amount per child as in normal schools. But the parents have to pay the difference if they want the higher quality. If the parents cannot afford, financial assistance is provided by the State, through Edusave scholarships, financial assistance schemes, and so on.

    With the experience of the independent schools, we are now establishing autonomous schools to benefit more pupils. Lessons learnt from both types of schools will be applied to upgrade our other schools, especially the neighbourhood schools which take in the bulk of our pupils. This process of levelling up is the formula for success to create future growth and prosperity so that we can continue to invest heavily in the education of our children and we can put aside surpluses every year into the Edusave fund to benefit many future generations of Singaporeans.

    Members have raised a few specific questions about the autonomous schools and I will cover them now. Firstly, the intention is to limit the autonomous schools to secondary schools. We will try it out with four to six schools first and over a period of time they may expand to 10 to 15 schools. There is no plan at the moment to include primary schools. But, in principle, why not, but perhaps at a later stage.

    Dr Toh asked whether we should revert RI to its original status. I do not think so. Children who are in the school are benefiting from the system and those who are not able to afford, they have all kinds of schemes to assist them. In fact, quite a large percentage, probably more than 50% of the children this year, are enjoying Edusave scholarships because they are top scholars. So, in fact, through this system they are able to get a better education and I think they deserve the best we can provide for them.

Column: 1045



    The autonomous schools will be somewhat different. In fact, we are trying to preserve the same ideas but with more funding from the Government. On the one hand, you have the independent schools. They will be free to experiment and they cost more because of the way they are operating. Having learnt from that, we are trying to establish an intermediate grade of schools known as autonomous schools which will be more like Government schools but with more funding, more autonomy and let us see how they operate. From then on, we can then evolve and try to improve on our education system.

    The staff of the autonomous schools will be staff of the Government under the Ministry. They will remain as staff of the Ministry. I think that has got its pros and cons. On the one hand, they will feel more secure because the Government system is a bigger system. On the other hand, Mr Low has mentioned that there is less flexibility to hire the staff. Perhaps that was Dr Toh's point, but I am not sure. We will allow the autonomous schools some flexibility in this area. For example, if they need to introduce enrichment programmes with the additional money which they will have, which will range from about $700,000 a year to about almost $1.2 million, they can hire specialist staff to provide enrichment programmes. So this will be the flexibility. They can also use the money to hire supporting staff and relieve the teachers of some of the teaching load. So on the whole, this will be a very good scheme and I hope more students will be able to benefit from the scheme.

    As we are running out of time, I will touch briefly on the Edusave points. Mr Lew Syn Pau asked whether we could extend the Edusave to the fourth and subsequent child of a mother. For the same reason that he gave that we have to be consistent with the population policy, the answer has to be "no" because the population policy is, in fact, have three or more if you can afford it. So if you cannot afford it, please do not have more than three children. We give to

Column: 1046

three, but any child beyond that you should provide yourself.

If there is any good idea, we would like to know about it. We propose that the deduction from the scheme should be at least $10 per case to minimise the administrative work. We should try and keep the administration as simple as possible.

So if these parents want to have the benefit of the Edusave scheme, they should put their children into our Government schools.
